title: Publication
description: The publication object is the core of Open Index, acting as a metadata wrapper for objects and thereby forming the common link between different publications from, for example, WOO and OC.

id.description: The unique identifier of this publication

summary.description: A short summary of the publication for the overview page

description.description: An extensive description of the publication for display on the publication page

image.description: An image for the publication, can be provided as a reference `url` or `base64` encoded image

category.description: The category within which the publication falls, these can be self-defined categories or predefined categories

portal.description: An optional reference to a different publication page, for example in the RIS

publicationDate.description: Date from when this publication should be discoverable, this can be a date in the future or past. Publications where this date is in the future or is blank will **NOT** be displayed in queries of the search API **UNLESS** the call is authenticated.

featured.description: `Featured` can be used to indicate that a publication should be discoverable on, for example, the homepage of a publication platform. From the API perspective, this property merely acts as a flag to find the items that are featured faster. The actual functionality of feature can thus vary per publication platform.

organization.description: The organization belonging to this publication object, in theory multiple organizations can share one Open Index installation but this is discouraged.

schema.description: Schemas add predictability and interpretability to the objects published under `data`. They describe the object contained in `data` and the conditions it must meet. For this, we use the [json-schema](https://json-schema.org/) which is itself part of [OAS 3](https://swagger.io/specification/). In the `schema` property, we expect a URL reference to a publicly accessible schema.json object. This could be on a website or GitHub, for instance. During `POST` and `PUT` actions on the publication object, the object in `data` is tested against this schema. Additionally, a consuming party can use the URL to retrieve the schema so they can interpret the object in `data`.

themes.description: The urls of the theme's associated with this publication

data.description: The actual object to be published (must not be larger than 15 MB)
